defeat of the seniors, the freshmen
getting the better end of a 33-to-17
score. The freshmen, as a whole,
presented a well-balanced team.
The senior team lacks organization
and team work, which is plainly the
result of the absence of practice, for
the fourth-year men possess some
very good material.
The candidates for the class teams
up to the present time are:
Seniors—Bagley (captain), Beck
(manager), Hayes, McDowell,
Knipp, Friedenwald, Rosenthal,
Baer and Rosen.
Juniors—Brooks (captain), McKewen (manager), P. Sutton, Baker, Boyce, Defandorf, Watson,
Gorman, Levin and Edlavitch.
Sophomores — Edgerton (captain), Love (manager), F. Sutton,
Sullivan, Jacobson, Ewing, Witz,
Evans and Golder.
Freshmen — Bitter (captain),

MANY WORTHLESS BOOKS BEING
DISCARDED AS LIBRARY MOVES

The work of moving the library
to the new site at Homewood, now
in progress, has offered many problems and features of interest.
Those in charge are now busy
with the work of picking out from
among the books in the library such
worthless material as can be discarded. So far eighty mail sacks
of books, largely duplicate governmental tmd State reports, have been
sent back to the departments from
which they came.
A contract has just been let for
the erection of steel book stacks
along one quarter of one wall of
the basement of Gilman Hall. Here
the biological department will be
placed, and the space created by
these new stacks will he sufficient
to hold twice the number of books
in the present biological library.
The geologists will be quartered
in the Civil Engineering Building,
which is now under construction
and which will be finished by next
fall. The coming summer school
will be the last to use the present
Hopkins buildings.

State Gathering to Be Held at Western
Maryland College, February 4 to 6.
Prominent Speakers Engaged.

JEWELRY
Fine Diamonds and Watches

The State Missionary Conference
of Maryland colleges will be held
this year at Western Maryland
College, Westminster, from February 4 to 6, inclusive.
In view of the widespread interest that always attends these
meetings, the Conference has taken
special pains to secure able and
widely-known leaders who are authorities on their subjects. A partial list of these follows:
Mr. Philip Swartz, of the Student Volunker Movement, New
York.
Dr. Paul Harrison, of Arabia, a
former Hopkins student.
Dr. Mary Stone, the foremost
woman physician in China, and a
brilliant speaker.
Dr. Adams, who has been in
China thirteen years as a missionary.
Arthur R. Knipp, professor in
Canton Christian College. Mr.
Knipp is a missionary of wide experience. After completing his
course of lectures he will come to
Hopkins and conduct a class on
"Students of Asia."
The Conference opens Friday
night, February 4, 1916, and will
be composed of representatives from
every college in Maryland. The
Hopkins and Goucher delegates
are planning to make this trip over
the bus line. An invitation is extended to all Hopkins men to attend. Those who wish to be members of the delegation will please
hand their names to R. E. F. Aler,
'16. Western Maryland College
will entertain the delegates. Expenses will not exceed two dollars
for each individual.

The recent victory of the freshman class in the track meet with
the sophomores and the continued
success of the first-year basket-ball
team show clearly that the class
has used the time between October
and January to good advantage;
that it has effected in that time a
good organization. The freshmen
deserve full recognition Of their attainments, and, if they are to develop into good Hopkins upperclassmen, they should be encouraged
to continue the efficient expenditure
of their efforts which they have
shown themselves capable of handling. With that idea in mind, THE
NEWS-LETTER desires to express its
hope that nothing of the spirit of
the freshmen will be lost and that
much will be gained by them to
the benefit of Johns Hopkins during
the four years in which it will be
their,privilege to be joined together
as a class.
It is too often the case that these
four years prove too a short a time
for a class to perfect an acceptable
organization. Most classes succeed
in working together as a unit by the
January of their freshman year,
but too many lose the organization
after the cessation of activities of
their sophomore year. Some never
get together to produce good results; others get together, stay together and make their four years
oi college a joy to themselves and
a period of prosperity for the University. Which type are the two
under-classes of today going to fol•
low?

It is almost needless to point out
that organization is always a necessary foundation.for successful class
work; it is not needless, however,
for some classes to be prodded
along in their loose and lazy habits
of taking up matters of importance.
It is the opinion of THE NEwsLETTER that classes at Hopkins are
pi one to lose whatever organization
they may have effected as freshmen
and sophomores before they enter
into their last year of college, life.
Freshmen and sophomores of today
should take heed that they do not
lose spirit from now on, or allow
themselves to suffer a reaction.
Steady progress is that which produces results. Spasmodic outbursts
of enthusiasm and ability can or
themselves avail little.
That internal organization is"
necessary in class work after the
strenuous rivalry of freshmansophomore days are over is demonstrated yearly by the spectacle of
the senior class working to finance
and edit its Hullabaloo. If we examine the condition of classes at
this stage of their existence, we see
immediately the effect of the presence or absence of well-founded organization. Its absence is the root
of needless worry and work on the
part of class officers; its presence
is the cause of every success. And,
above all, it cannot be well matured
in the senior year if there has been
a lack of spirit for any length of
time, or if organization itself was
never completed.
What the classes of 1918 and
1919 are going to do in this matter
remains to be seen. What they
should do has been pointed out; if
they do it, they will experience a
healthy existence throughout their
college career; if not, they are almost certain to have serious trouble.
Get together, systematize, and carry
out your system!

MUSICIANS TO OFFER GOOD SHOW

SENIORS' BENEFIT PROFITABLE

All Efforts Being Centered on McCoy
Hall Concert, Which Will Be the
Best in Years Prospects Otherwise Are Excellent.

Graduating Class Clears $145 on Pei
formance of "Rolling Stones" Was
Most Successful Benefit Held in
Many Years.

The work of the Musical Clubs
went ahead rapidly during the .past
week. The glee and mandolin clubs
held several successful rehearsals,
with the result that the affairs of
the clubs are in much better shape
than those of any club of the past
few years. As a consequence of
such favorable conditions, little
work remains to be done before
the clubs will be able to start their
schedule with confidence and success.
The repertoire of the glee club
will be unusually large this year,
and is composed of selections of
most varied character. Particular
care has been taken by the director
in selecting the songs for the vocalists, and the task of choosing those
selections which will appear on the
program and those which will be
used as encores will be a difficult
one. In general, the repertoire and
the unusual ability of this season's
club promises to surpass the high
standard set by last year's organization.
The progress of the mandolin
club, although less marked than that
of the glee club, due to the fact that
several of the instrumentalists attend classes at Homewood, has been
very encouraging. The mandolin
club is composed entirely of stringed
instruments, with the exception of
the traps. This is something of a
departure from the "instrumental"
club of past years, hence the change
in name. The repertoire of the
mandolin club offers numbers just
as well selected and varied as those
of the glee club. The better class
of music will appear on the program, while the "rags" will be retained to serve as encores.
The quartet, composed of Messrs.
Swartz, Spieker, Houghton and
Flack, has been rehearsing regularly and promises to have several
numbers a little different from those
offered in past years.
The complete schedule of concerts will be announced shortly.
Several dates have yet to be decided upon and arrangements for
several trips are still pending. The
schedule committee will present its
report to the board for approval
as soon as these details are settled.
All efforts are being concentrated
on the McCoy Hall concert, which
is to be given on Friday evening,
February 25. In past years this
concert has always been characterized by a very small number of undergraduate students in attendance.
This condition has been a matter of
great concern to the members of
the present board, inasmuch as the
Musical Clubs are composed almost
entirely of undergraduate students
and ought to arouse interest among
their .fellows. As a possible solution of this problem, a special ticket,
exchangeable for two reserved seat3,

The Senior Class scored a great
success in their Hullabaloo benefit,
held at Ford's last Friday night.
Besides seeing a most excellent play
admirably acted, the Hopkins supporters who were present were all
the more pleased because of the fact
that the seniors had disposed of
two hundred and ninety dollars'
worth of tickets, half of which is
clear profit for the Hullabaloo. The
committee has not as yet heard
from all those who sold tickets for
the benefit, and there is a possibility
that more money will be coming
into the class treasury.
The benefit committee was singularly , fortunate in being able to se'?
cure such a play as "Rolling Stones
for the benefit. The characters
were so natural and true to life,
even in unnatural and unusual circumstances, that the audience was
soon lost to everything else in its
interest in the play. "Rolling
Stones" has been described verT,
rightly as a "comedy of adventure."
There was plenty of comedy, and
also plenty of adventure. Every
comic part had a background of adventure and every adventure was
filled with comedy.
Charles Ruggles and Harrison
Ford took the parts of the "rolling
stones," and gave the audience as
clever and realistic a representation
of the two adventurous youths as
anyone could possible give. All
those in the cast were of exceptional
ability and were eminently fitted to
their parts.
The success of the seniors in disposing of so many of their tickets
will materially aid the Hullabaloo
editors in their efforts to produce
a good year-book. Every year the
publishers of the Hullabaloo have
difficulty in raising the funds necessary for the expenses of printing
the book, and the support given the
Class of '16 was gratifying n6t only
to the seniors, but to everyone interested in Hopkin's affairs. There
was a larger attendance at Friday
night's performance than has ever
before been seen at a Hopkins benefit, and this, together with the fact
that the play was most enjoyable,
marks this event as a most decided
success.
will be offered to undergraduate
students at the reduced rate of
$1.50. Only one of these tickets
will be allowed each student. Additional tickets must be obtained at
the regular rate of $1.00 admission.
All seats will be reserved.
Arrangements have been made
to have the usual dance follow the
concert. The management feels
fortunate in being able to announce
that the renowned Louis Fisher will
be on hand with three of his musicians to furnish the dance music.

Sec. 7. Infringements of this
agreement are of two classes—those
offenses due to ignorance or misinterpretation are the first class;
those known and planned by a fraternity member form the second
class. It is the duty of the trying
board to decide from the evidence
offered whether an offense be of
the first or second class, and to
fix a punishment in proportion
to the offense. The maximum penalty for the first class of offenses
shall be the suspension of the
right of the offending fraternity to
rush during a period of the rush'ing season, fixed at the discretion
of the Board. The maximum penalty of the second class of offenses
shall be the withdrawal of the right
of the offending fraternity to initiate or pledge any men of the period
of one year.
These penalties shall be inflicted
the year following the one in which
the offense occurs.
The results of the trial and the
penalty imposed shall be made public at Johns Hopkins.
The fraternities hereby agree that
no fraternity which has had judgment passed against it shall withdraw from the agreement until ;t

Opportunity to Do Good.
To the Editor of THE NEws-LETTER:

Sir—In the last edition of THE
NEWS LETTER I noticed an appeal
was issued by the Young Men's
Christian Association to the members of the University to teach English to a number of Poles scattered
throughout the city, as well as to aid
some "poor but worthy boys" in
their enterprises.
This work should receive the support of all who are fitted for it, as
it is an opportunity to do real good,
and to materially aid in the development of the country; for, if the boys
are brought into a good environment, it will have an inestimable
good effect on their lives, and if the
men are taught to speak English,
their standard of efficiency will be
considerably enhanced.
And, here is a chance, furthermore, to prove to those who are
skeptical as to the value of a college education, that it develops
men who have more serious interests than athletics and social activities; who are willing to share
with others the benefits of the education they have received; who can
turn this education into a practical
means for doing good for a community to whose needs they are
thoroughly awake; and, .who are
good citizens—not merely in the
passive, but in the active sense of
the word.
Report to a member of the committee "and offer your services! Remember, that in this as in all other
college activities "Hopkins expects
every man to do his duty."
X. Y. Z.

MANY WORTHLESS BOOKS BEING
DISCARDED AS LIBRARY MOVES

The work of moving the library
to the new site at Homewood, now
in progress, has offered many problems and features of interest.
Those in charge are now busy
with the work of picking out from
among the books in the library such
worthless material as can be discarded. So far eighty mail sacks
of books, largely duplicate governmental tmd State reports, have been
sent back to the departments from
which they came.
A contract has just been let for
the erection of steel book stacks
along one quarter of one wall of
the basement of Gilman Hall. Here
the biological department will be
placed, and the space created by
these new stacks will he sufficient
to hold twice the number of books
in the present biological library.
The geologists will be quartered
in the Civil Engineering Building,
which is now under construction
and which will be finished by next
fall. The coming summer school
will be the last to use the present
Hopkins buildings.

Tau Kappa Alpha, Honorary Debating
Fraternity, Seeks to Found Branch
at Hopkins -Viginia's Subject

State Gathering to Be Held at Western
Maryland College, February 4 to 6.
Prominent Speakers Engaged.

JEWELRY
Fine Diamonds and Watches

The State Missionary Conference
of Maryland colleges will be held
this year at Western Maryland
College, Westminster, from February 4 to 6, inclusive.
In view of the widespread interest that always attends these
meetings, the Conference has taken
special pains to secure able and
widely-known leaders who are authorities on their subjects. A partial list of these follows:
Mr. Philip Swartz, of the Student Volunker Movement, New
York.
Dr. Paul Harrison, of Arabia, a
former Hopkins student.
Dr. Mary Stone, the foremost
woman physician in China, and a
brilliant speaker.
Dr. Adams, who has been in
China thirteen years as a missionary.
Arthur R. Knipp, professor in
Canton Christian College. Mr.
Knipp is a missionary of wide experience. After completing his
course of lectures he will come to
Hopkins and conduct a class on
"Students of Asia."
The Conference opens Friday
night, February 4, 1916, and will
be composed of representatives from
every college in Maryland. The
Hopkins and Goucher delegates
are planning to make this trip over
the bus line. An invitation is extended to all Hopkins men to attend. Those who wish to be members of the delegation will please
hand their names to R. E. F. Aler,
'16. Western Maryland College
will entertain the delegates. Expenses will not exceed two dollars
for each individual.

The recent victory of the freshman class in the track meet with
the sophomores and the continued
success of the first-year basket-ball
team show clearly that the class
has used the time between October
and January to good advantage;
that it has effected in that time a
good organization. The freshmen
deserve full recognition Of their attainments, and, if they are to develop into good Hopkins upperclassmen, they should be encouraged
to continue the efficient expenditure
of their efforts which they have
shown themselves capable of handling. With that idea in mind, THE
NEWS-LETTER desires to express its
hope that nothing of the spirit of
the freshmen will be lost and that
much will be gained by them to
the benefit of Johns Hopkins during
the four years in which it will be
their,privilege to be joined together
as a class.
It is too often the case that these
four years prove too a short a time
for a class to perfect an acceptable
organization. Most classes succeed
in working together as a unit by the
January of their freshman year,
but too many lose the organization
after the cessation of activities of
their sophomore year. Some never
get together to produce good results; others get together, stay together and make their four years
oi college a joy to themselves and
a period of prosperity for the University. Which type are the two
under-classes of today going to fol•
low?

It is almost needless to point out
that organization is always a necessary foundation.for successful class
work; it is not needless, however,
for some classes to be prodded
along in their loose and lazy habits
of taking up matters of importance.
It is the opinion of THE NEwsLETTER that classes at Hopkins are
pi one to lose whatever organization
they may have effected as freshmen
and sophomores before they enter
into their last year of college, life.
Freshmen and sophomores of today
should take heed that they do not
lose spirit from now on, or allow
themselves to suffer a reaction.
Steady progress is that which produces results. Spasmodic outbursts
of enthusiasm and ability can or
themselves avail little.
That internal organization is"
necessary in class work after the
strenuous rivalry of freshmansophomore days are over is demonstrated yearly by the spectacle of
the senior class working to finance
and edit its Hullabaloo. If we examine the condition of classes at
this stage of their existence, we see
immediately the effect of the presence or absence of well-founded organization. Its absence is the root
of needless worry and work on the
part of class officers; its presence
is the cause of every success. And,
above all, it cannot be well matured
in the senior year if there has been
a lack of spirit for any length of
time, or if organization itself was
never completed.
What the classes of 1918 and
1919 are going to do in this matter
remains to be seen. What they
should do has been pointed out; if
they do it, they will experience a
healthy existence throughout their
college career; if not, they are almost certain to have serious trouble.
Get together, systematize, and carry
out your system!

MUSICIANS TO OFFER GOOD SHOW

SENIORS' BENEFIT PROFITABLE

All Efforts Being Centered on McCoy
Hall Concert, Which Will Be the
Best in Years Prospects Otherwise Are Excellent.

Graduating Class Clears $145 on Pei
formance of "Rolling Stones" Was
Most Successful Benefit Held in
Many Years.

The work of the Musical Clubs
went ahead rapidly during the .past
week. The glee and mandolin clubs
held several successful rehearsals,
with the result that the affairs of
the clubs are in much better shape
than those of any club of the past
few years. As a consequence of
such favorable conditions, little
work remains to be done before
the clubs will be able to start their
schedule with confidence and success.
The repertoire of the glee club
will be unusually large this year,
and is composed of selections of
most varied character. Particular
care has been taken by the director
in selecting the songs for the vocalists, and the task of choosing those
selections which will appear on the
program and those which will be
used as encores will be a difficult
one. In general, the repertoire and
the unusual ability of this season's
club promises to surpass the high
standard set by last year's organization.
The progress of the mandolin
club, although less marked than that
of the glee club, due to the fact that
several of the instrumentalists attend classes at Homewood, has been
very encouraging. The mandolin
club is composed entirely of stringed
instruments, with the exception of
the traps. This is something of a
departure from the "instrumental"
club of past years, hence the change
in name. The repertoire of the
mandolin club offers numbers just
as well selected and varied as those
of the glee club. The better class
of music will appear on the program, while the "rags" will be retained to serve as encores.
The quartet, composed of Messrs.
Swartz, Spieker, Houghton and
Flack, has been rehearsing regularly and promises to have several
numbers a little different from those
offered in past years.
The complete schedule of concerts will be announced shortly.
Several dates have yet to be decided upon and arrangements for
several trips are still pending. The
schedule committee will present its
report to the board for approval
as soon as these details are settled.
All efforts are being concentrated
on the McCoy Hall concert, which
is to be given on Friday evening,
February 25. In past years this
concert has always been characterized by a very small number of undergraduate students in attendance.
This condition has been a matter of
great concern to the members of
the present board, inasmuch as the
Musical Clubs are composed almost
entirely of undergraduate students
and ought to arouse interest among
their .fellows. As a possible solution of this problem, a special ticket,
exchangeable for two reserved seat3,

The Senior Class scored a great
success in their Hullabaloo benefit,
held at Ford's last Friday night.
Besides seeing a most excellent play
admirably acted, the Hopkins supporters who were present were all
the more pleased because of the fact
that the seniors had disposed of
two hundred and ninety dollars'
worth of tickets, half of which is
clear profit for the Hullabaloo. The
committee has not as yet heard
from all those who sold tickets for
the benefit, and there is a possibility
that more money will be coming
into the class treasury.
The benefit committee was singularly , fortunate in being able to se'?
cure such a play as "Rolling Stones
for the benefit. The characters
were so natural and true to life,
even in unnatural and unusual circumstances, that the audience was
soon lost to everything else in its
interest in the play. "Rolling
Stones" has been described verT,
rightly as a "comedy of adventure."
There was plenty of comedy, and
also plenty of adventure. Every
comic part had a background of adventure and every adventure was
filled with comedy.
Charles Ruggles and Harrison
Ford took the parts of the "rolling
stones," and gave the audience as
clever and realistic a representation
of the two adventurous youths as
anyone could possible give. All
those in the cast were of exceptional
ability and were eminently fitted to
their parts.
The success of the seniors in disposing of so many of their tickets
will materially aid the Hullabaloo
editors in their efforts to produce
a good year-book. Every year the
publishers of the Hullabaloo have
difficulty in raising the funds necessary for the expenses of printing
the book, and the support given the
Class of '16 was gratifying n6t only
to the seniors, but to everyone interested in Hopkin's affairs. There
was a larger attendance at Friday
night's performance than has ever
before been seen at a Hopkins benefit, and this, together with the fact
that the play was most enjoyable,
marks this event as a most decided
success.

students at the reduced rate of
$1.50. Only one of these tickets
will be allowed each student. Additional tickets must be obtained at
the regular rate of $1.00 admission.
All seats will be reserved.
Arrangements have been made
to have the usual dance follow the
concert. The management feels
fortunate in being able to announce
that the renowned Louis Fisher will
be on hand with three of his musicians to furnish the dance music.

Sec. 7. Infringements of this
agreement are of two classes—those
offenses due to ignorance or misinterpretation are the first class;
those known and planned by a fraternity member form the second
class. It is the duty of the trying
board to decide from the evidence
offered whether an offense be of
the first or second class, and to
fix a punishment in proportion
to the offense. The maximum penalty for the first class of offenses
shall be the suspension of the
right of the offending fraternity to
rush during a period of the rush'ing season, fixed at the discretion
of the Board. The maximum penalty of the second class of offenses
shall be the withdrawal of the right
of the offending fraternity to initiate or pledge any men of the period
of one year.
These penalties shall be inflicted
the year following the one in which
the offense occurs.
The results of the trial and the
penalty imposed shall be made public at Johns Hopkins.
The fraternities hereby agree that
no fraternity which has had judgment passed against it shall withdraw from the agreement until ;t
has served its punishment.

Dr. Raney to Publish Editorials.

Dr. L. F. Raney, as secretary of
the Maryland Wild Life Protective
Association, has written a series of
eight special editorials on "The Conservation of Wild Life," which will
appear in the State and city papers
on eight.consecutive Monday afternoons.
Opportunity to Do Good.
To the Editor of THE NEws-LETTER:

Sir—In the last edition of THE
NEWS LETTER I noticed an appeal
was issued by the Young Men's
Christian Association to the members of the University to teach English to a number of Poles scattered
throughout the city, as well as to aid
some "poor but worthy boys" in
their enterprises.
This work should receive the support of all who are fitted for it, as
it is an opportunity to do real good,
and to materially aid in the development of the country; for, if the boys
are brought into a good environment, it will have an inestimable
good effect on their lives, and if the
men are taught to speak English,
their standard of efficiency will be
considerably enhanced.
And, here is a chance, furthermore, to prove to those who are
skeptical as to the value of a college education, that it develops
men who have more serious interests than athletics and social activities; who are willing to share
with others the benefits of the education they have received; who can
turn this education into a practical
means for doing good for a community to whose needs they are
thoroughly awake; and, .who are
good citizens—not merely in the
passive, but in the active sense of
the word.
Report to a member of the committee "and offer your services! Remember, that in this as in all other
college activities "Hopkins expects
every man to do his duty."
X. Y. Z.
January 20, 1916.
